quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When you're looking for a job, you need a spear and not a net.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A memorable framework for focusing your job search on a narrow target instead of applying broadly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So what I ask people to do is I ask them to think about what they want and what they don't want.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Actionable advice to clarify criteria up front so your search is guided by explicit preferences rather than panic.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Now, you might not think that that's a radical step, Lenny, but most people don't do that. When they get laid off, they spray and pray.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A contrarian observation that challenges the common “apply everywhere” approach and explains why it fails.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Well, there is an I in village, and the I in village is that when you start to interview and negotiate, you've got to be in charge. I want you to play to win, not not to lose.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A negotiation mindset shift: take ownership of the process and optimize for winning rather than avoiding rejection.

quotes.topic_title: What Job Search Councils are
quotes.text: It's a support group of six to eight job seekers, so product people, but it is not just for product people, but the product community really owns this, it comes out of the product community.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Defines the core structure and size of a Job Search Council as a practical, replicable peer-support format.

quotes.topic_title: What Job Search Councils are
quotes.text: And what they do is they commit to being with each other, to supporting each other, go through the process of looking for a job and I lay out a methodology, how to figure out your candidate market fit, one of the big concepts in the book.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Highlights the commitment mechanism plus a concrete methodology (“candidate market fit”) that practitioners can apply.

quotes.topic_title: What Job Search Councils are
quotes.text: everyone, I mean everyone, and I work with some of the most senior people in Silicon Valley, I'm talking about CEOs of public companies, I'm talking about chief product officers, VPs of product at great brands, everyone, no matter who they are, Lenny, feels insecure and anxious in the job search. And if you do it alone, it magnifies that.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A counterintuitive normalization of job-search anxiety—even at the highest levels—and a warning about the costs of going solo.

quotes.topic_title: What Job Search Councils are
quotes.text: if you put anxious people together and ask them to be open and vulnerable and to ask for help, and we'll come back to asking for help, it actually flips the anxiety and the fear into hope, into motivation, into accountability and confidence.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Provides a practical psychological “hack” for transforming job-search emotions into productive behaviors via group vulnerability and help-seeking.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: Phyl’s mom and tough markets
quotes.text: That group met for 50 years, 5-0, until the year she died. They worked together to ask for help and support each other in their careers.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Highlights the long-running “council” as a durable career-support system built on explicit help-seeking and mutual support.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: Phyl’s mom and tough markets
quotes.text: And Lenny, people say to me, "Does this Never Search Alone method work in a tough job market?" And I'll tell you, it comes out of tough job markets. Absolutely, yes. Starting with my mom.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A contrarian claim that the method is not just resilient in downturns—it was designed in and for them.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: Phyl’s mom and tough markets
quotes.text: Her candidate market fit was terrible, but she had her council.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“candidate market fit”) paired with the practical counterbalance of a support council.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: Phyl’s mom and tough markets
quotes.text: The job she could get, guess what? She had to be an entry level teacher again after having been a senior teacher coaching and advising.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concrete example of how tough markets can force senior candidates into entry-level roles, underscoring the need for support and strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The most successful people that I know surround themselves with incredible peers.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A simple, actionable principle: deliberately build a high-caliber peer circle as a career accelerant.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When you have a trusted group of peers, you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just gut-check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Defines a practical use-case framework for peer groups: problem-solving, advice, and decision validation across work and life.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But it's hard to build this trusted group of peers on your own.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “networking” isn’t enough—curating a trusted peer group is non-trivial and often needs structure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: 93% of members say Sidebar helped them achieve a significant positive change in their career.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concrete outcome metric that quantifies the claimed impact of structured peer groups.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: these challenges require a deep understanding of your users, something that you can't get from product analytics alone.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A practical product insight: analytics must be complemented with qualitative/experience data to understand user intent and friction.

quotes.topic_title: Scale, funding, and how councils operate
quotes.text: We have launched more than 2,000 of these Lenny, 2,000, and they're completely free, completely 100% free. It's volunteer-driven.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concrete scale + operating model data point that shows how a large job-search support system can run without charging participants.

quotes.topic_title: Scale, funding, and how councils operate
quotes.text: So we have 20,000 hours of volunteer time, but you also have to pay for technology and you have to pay for certain kinds of support.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Highlights the practical resourcing reality: even “free” programs need a plan for non-labor costs.

quotes.topic_title: Scale, funding, and how councils operate
quotes.text: If you're in a job and looking, we call you a slow seeker because you have a full-time job and you can't work as quickly. If you're out of work and looking, we call you a fast seeker and we put you in different groups.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A simple segmentation framework (fast vs. slow seekers) that practitioners can apply to tailor cadence and expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Scale, funding, and how councils operate
quotes.text: If you volunteer to moderate, first of all, you get matched faster, and secondly, you get more training and support.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Counterintuitive tactic: taking on a leadership role can accelerate access and increase support during a job search.

quotes.topic_title: Scale, funding, and how councils operate
quotes.text: And you do a first meeting, we call it meeting zero, where you're open and vulnerable. People share stories about their lives and who they are, builds trust and get a sense of who people are.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for quickly building trust and cohesion before moving into execution-oriented job-search work.

quotes.topic_title: Impact stories and emotional balance sheet
quotes.text: As a product leader, I love how it has you apply the product process to your career.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Highlights a transferable methodology: treating your job search like a product process to make it more systematic and effective.

quotes.topic_title: Impact stories and emotional balance sheet
quotes.text: Not only does your JSC help bounce ideas and help your job search, they also help you keep going and accountable when you're low on emotional energy.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Explains the practical value of a council as an accountability and resilience mechanism, especially when motivation dips.

quotes.topic_title: Impact stories and emotional balance sheet
quotes.text: All those things are really important, but the most important thing to manage is your emotional balance.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization: emotional management outranks typical job-search tactics like resume, LinkedIn, and networking.

quotes.topic_title: Impact stories and emotional balance sheet
quotes.text: I talk about your emotional balance sheet.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model for tracking and managing the emotional “assets” and “liabilities” that affect job-search performance.

quotes.topic_title: Impact stories and emotional balance sheet
quotes.text: The job search, it can be hard and humiliating at times.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Normalizes the emotional reality of job searching, reinforcing why support structures and process matter in a down market.

quotes.topic_title: Why you shouldn’t search alone
quotes.text: This is unusual, what we're doing here. This is not how people look for a job. We're trying to disrupt the job search process.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Frames councils as a deliberate, non-traditional methodology for job searching rather than incremental tweaks to solo searching.

quotes.topic_title: Why you shouldn’t search alone
quotes.text: Oh my God, I couldn't believe it. The level of trust we created right off the bat I've never experienced in my life. It's really truly accountability, the motivation, the ability to hang in there.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concrete success story highlighting the practical mechanisms (trust + accountability) that make councils effective, even for introverts.

quotes.topic_title: Why you shouldn’t search alone
quotes.text: Look, try it.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Actionable advice: treat joining a council as a low-risk experiment rather than a big commitment decision.

quotes.topic_title: Why you shouldn’t search alone
quotes.text: We live in a world where there's increasing loneliness, Lenny. There's so much research about this, the Surgeon General's book, everybody talking about... And it's more detrimental to our health than smoking cigarettes.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A striking data point that reframes job-search support groups as a health-relevant antidote to loneliness, not just a career tactic.

quotes.topic_title: Why you shouldn’t search alone
quotes.text: I don't mean message boards, I mean real community.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Draws a sharp, counterintuitive distinction between passive online interaction and high-trust community as the real lever for progress.

quotes.topic_title: Building a private safety net and mission
quotes.text: If we go up to the 30,000-foot level, what are we doing here? What's our mission? We're building a private safety net for all those who've been laid off or let go.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Defines a clear mission framing—positioning the work as a “private safety net” for people impacted by layoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Building a private safety net and mission
quotes.text: But the government's never going to be able to innovate around how to actually look for a job. That's where we come in.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A contrarian division of labor: government can provide insurance, but innovation in job search support must come from elsewhere.

quotes.topic_title: Building a private safety net and mission
quotes.text: Creative destruction basically says, "Under capitalism, it's dynamic. New products and services displace or disrupt old products and services, companies and methods."
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Introduces the core mental model (creative destruction) to explain why layoffs and churn are structural, not anomalous.

quotes.topic_title: Building a private safety net and mission
quotes.text: It's why our economy has grown sixfold over the last a hundred years.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concrete data point used to justify why creative destruction is worth preserving despite its downsides.

quotes.topic_title: Building a private safety net and mission
quotes.text: All of us who benefited from this, I think it's our duty to do something about it.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A memorable call-to-action that turns an economic observation into a practitioner’s moral imperative to build support systems.

quotes.topic_title: Candidate market fit: concept and first steps
quotes.text: So let's say you're a director of product. Two years ago when the economy was great in tech and the job market was great in tech, you could probably get a VP of product role. What about today? Well, today your candidate market fit's been pushed down because there's a bunch of VPs of products who are going to take a director role. Guess what? That means you might not be able to get the director role you might need to get a senior manager role or whatever.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Concrete supply/demand example showing how market conditions can “push down” role level expectations independent of individual capability.

quotes.topic_title: Candidate market fit: concept and first steps
quotes.text: Now, the important thing about this is it's not a personal segment about you. It's the marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Reframes job search outcomes as market dynamics rather than personal worth, reducing unproductive self-blame.

quotes.topic_title: Candidate market fit: concept and first steps
quotes.text: When they get laid off, they spray and pray.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Calls out a common but ineffective default behavior that undermines a focused job search strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Candidate market fit: concept and first steps
quotes.text: I'm like, "I'm going to slow you down to go fast."
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Memorable principle advocating an upfront strategy pause to accelerate results later.

quotes.topic_title: Candidate market fit: concept and first steps
quotes.text: In fact, what our data shows is that the average job search in the Job Search Council from beginning to end is three months. If you look at the national data for job search, it's three to six months. So we are at the very low end of the national average.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Provides a comparative data point suggesting structured process can shorten time-to-job versus national averages.

quotes.topic_title: Listening tour: market research and relationships
quotes.text: Because guess what? In the job search, we're the product. We're our skills and experience. That's the product that we're bringing to market. So we have to go see what the market wants.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Reframes job searching as product/market fit work, pushing practitioners to validate demand rather than only preferences.

quotes.topic_title: Listening tour: market research and relationships
quotes.text: Because I asked them to ask a golden question, if you were in my shoes, how would you approach this? I call that the golden question.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, repeatable prompt that elicits high-quality guidance and opens up deeper conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Listening tour: market research and relationships
quotes.text: So the secret about the listening tour is that not only are you getting market research customer feedback on your fit, you're also creating a whole group of listening posts, people who are invested in your success.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive benefit that asking for help (well) builds an invested support network, not just information.

quotes.topic_title: Listening tour: market research and relationships
quotes.text: Recruiters don't like being barraged with, "Get me a job." They do like someone saying, "Hey, what do you think I'm a fit for?" asking their advice.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Gives a practical messaging shift for engaging recruiters more effectively by seeking fit feedback instead of job requests.

quotes.topic_title: Listening tour: market research and relationships
quotes.text: When that recruiter calls, pick up the phone even if you don't want the job, help them, network with them, introduce them to other people, and build that relationship, because whether you lose a job or whether you decide to start looking when you're in work, you want that relationship.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Actionable long-term tactic: proactively invest in recruiter relationships before you need them to improve future job-search leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing your CMF: spear not a net
quotes.text: when you're looking for a job, you need a spear and not a net. With a net, everything slips through.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why narrowing your target role/company profile increases traction versus trying to appeal to everyone.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing your CMF: spear not a net
quotes.text: people are expansive, but not reductive.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A counterintuitive principle explaining why a specific ask helps others generate adjacent opportunities, while a broad ask makes you forgettable.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing your CMF: spear not a net
quotes.text: If I told you, "Hey, Lenny, I'll take any product job I can," you are never going to think of me. You're never going to remember me. You're not going to be reductive from a broad statement, but you will be expansive from a narrow.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Concrete guidance on how to phrase your search so your network can actually match-make and refer you.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing your CMF: spear not a net
quotes.text: So it's typically three to four attributes, and we give people a whole grid in a set of examples.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A practical rule-of-thumb for constructing a 1-sentence candidate market fit statement that’s narrow enough to be useful.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing your CMF: spear not a net
quotes.text: So we had a woman who was a designer. She was a product designer. And what her product market fit was, she was looking for companies that either did not have a design team or needed to reboot one.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A specific example showing how CMF can be defined by a company’s need-state (not just industry or stage) to create a vivid referral hook.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing attributes and stage; startups vs big tech
quotes.text: Stage of company, industry, level of role and function, of course, and culture.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concise “grid” framework for defining your target roles across stage, industry, level/function, and culture.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing attributes and stage; startups vs big tech
quotes.text: But I tell people, make it simple. This should not be paragraphs and paragraphs. It should be a one-sentence statement.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to make your job-search positioning easy for others to remember and repeat.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing attributes and stage; startups vs big tech
quotes.text: there are more jobs in the startup world than there are in the established companies in the tech world for product people. That's where new job creation has been happening.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A market-dynamics data point suggesting startups may offer more openings than big tech right now.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing attributes and stage; startups vs big tech
quotes.text: Just know that if you're going to get any job just to have while you still look for the job you really want, just know that that's hard. That's a hard pen.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that taking a “bridge job” while searching can be harder than people expect.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing attributes and stage; startups vs big tech
quotes.text: It's harder than you realize, and you absolutely have to keep your job search council, because otherwise you're going to get lost.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Practical advice to maintain a support/accountability group to stay on track during a difficult search.

quotes.topic_title: Hard truths: downleveling, two-step strategies, frontier
quotes.text: What was their candidate market fit? They went out and did this, their candidate market fit, if they were going to join a top streamer was as an individual contributor, Lenny.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concrete example of downleveling as a strategic move to enter a top-tier company when prior senior experience isn’t valued by that market.

quotes.topic_title: Hard truths: downleveling, two-step strategies, frontier
quotes.text: They were just honest with him. And that's what Justin was talking about, this can be hard and humiliating at times to figure out...
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Highlights the “listening tour” reality-check as a practical (if uncomfortable) method for discovering true market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Hard truths: downleveling, two-step strategies, frontier
quotes.text: Sometimes you need a two-step strategy.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Introduces a reusable career-planning framework: take an intermediate role that positions you to reach the target role later.

quotes.topic_title: Hard truths: downleveling, two-step strategies, frontier
quotes.text: So he interviewed with 50 companies. 50. Can you imagine? It took them a year and a half. The 50th company hired him.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A vivid data point illustrating how persistence without market-fit adjustment can be extremely costly in time and effort.

quotes.topic_title: Hard truths: downleveling, two-step strategies, frontier
quotes.text: You got to get closer to the technology frontier, even if that means you're going to go from the EVP to an IC role.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A blunt, actionable heuristic for long-term career resilience: prioritize proximity to the tech frontier over title.

quotes.topic_title: Staying active: updates, accountability, and the 'I in village'
quotes.text: One of the tactics, Lenny, I tell people is you've got to send out an update note every month to all of your network that you've talked to.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable networking system (monthly updates) to stay top-of-mind during a job search.

quotes.topic_title: Staying active: updates, accountability, and the 'I in village'
quotes.text: Don't make that mistake. You got to do that.
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Emphasizes that consistent updates are a critical lever people commonly underuse, even when advised to do so.

quotes.topic_title: Staying active: updates, accountability, and the 'I in village'
quotes.text: They stopped network. They left their job search council. They weren't updating their candidate market fit to the changing market condition. I'm like, "You have to do everything. You can't get passive."
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: Diagnoses why long searches stall and frames passivity as the core failure mode to actively guard against.

quotes.topic_title: Staying active: updates, accountability, and the 'I in village'
quotes.text: One of the concepts, Lenny, I talk about is you've got to be the I in village. There's no I in team. Well, there is an I in village, okay?
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes community support as increasing personal agency rather than reducing independence.

quotes.topic_title: Staying active: updates, accountability, and the 'I in village'
quotes.text: He was like, "Phyl, I love you, but this candidate market fit stuff, no. You're wrong. It needs to be [inaudible 00:46:57]." And so he went out and he actually spoke to a bunch of VCs and like, " We don't have any idea what to do with you. You have to tell us something really specific."
quotes.speaker: Phyl Terry
quotes.context: A specific example showing how senior candidates get rejected for being too broad, reinforcing the need for a narrow, specific positioning.
